Sorry, I cannot reproduce and from looking at the code it shouldn't happen. Was that PHP file edited in a PHP editor or just in the normal Text Editor?  Were there other errors in the .log?

Please reopen if you can provide more details as currently there's not much we can do here.

This was a plain text editor (Right-click > Open With > Text Editor).
The file is CVS controlled.

Before the assertion, I had been editing Manifests and fell into bug #191094 (.log file attached there). Before that, I had seen multiple NPEs with CVS/Compare, logged as bug #190778, .log is attached there as well.

I'm sorry that I've removed my current .log already, but I'm 95% sure that there were no other exceptions logged between the PDE issue and this assertion failed issue.

More info about my configuration: 
  eclipse-SDK 3.3rc3, 
  releng.tools 3.3rc3,
  cdt 4.0rc2,
  emf 2.3.0rc1,
  RSE SDK 2.0rc1,
  Subclipse 1.1.9,
  Wind River Internal Retriever Feature (an indexed text search engine)

More info about my Workbench:
  PDE Perspective, views on top:
    Package Explorer, Editor, Outline, Errorlog
  Other open views (stacked behind):
    Hierarchy, Resource Navigator (left pane);
    Tasks, Problems, History, Console, Debug, Progress, Search (lower pane).

Adding Markus Schorn on CC, he wrote the "Wind River Internal Retriever" and might be able to comment on the possibility of it influencing the quickdiff which seems to be throwing the assertion.

Reopening as requested because I do think I have more info.

PS is it normal that Eclipse runs with assertions enabled?
Here is the commandline script I'm using for starting:

SET EHOME=E:\PDE\eclipse3.3rc3\eclipse
SET ECLIPSE=%EHOME%\eclipse.exe
SET ECLWS=F:/WS/RSE.new/ws
SET ECLVM=
SET ECLCFG=
SET ECLOPT=%ECLVM% %ECLCFG% -keyring E:\PDE\prefs\ring\.keyring -vmargs -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote
start %ECLIPSE% -data %ECLWS% %ECLOPT%

I do not see -vmargs -ea here so I'm surprised... adding Kim and Andrew on CC to clarify why I'm running with assertions enabled.

>PS is it normal that Eclipse runs with assertions enabled?
Eclipse SDK code normally doesn't use the Java assert feature. We use org.eclipse.core.runtime.Assert for code that wants to ensure hard asertions.

No need to reopen the bug as I can't do much without steps / further info.

> I was typing text in a file "text.de" at the end. 
Which editor? Do you have reproducible steps?

(In reply to comment #8)
> > I was typing text in a file "text.de" at the end. 
> Which editor? Do you have reproducible steps?
> 

I have experimented exactly the same bug, and i think i kwnow why
and how to reproduce it.

The logic of org.eclipse.ui.internal.texteditor.quickdiff.DocumentLineDiffer.handleAboutToBeChanged
assumes that IDocumentListener.documentChanged is always called after a IDocumentListener.documentAboutToBeChanged.

This is clearly wrong if a listener called after the one that calls documentAboutToBeChanged raises an exception.

In that case, the field containing the thread in DocumentLineDiffer is not reset
to null. And any futher call to DocumentLineDiffer.handleAboutToBeChanged
will throw the assertion exception.

I think DocumentLineDiffer need to be patch to to better handle that case.

Steps to reproduce:
create an editor (i think you can use the one that parse an XML document
provided as a demo to show how an editor works).
raise an exception in a IDocumentListener, in my example it was in a
in the method createPresentation of an editor presentation repairer (IPresentationRepairer).

best regards,
R?mi
But if so, that exception should be seen in the .log or console too.
